awd_titl_txt: Understanding How Narrative Elements Can Shape Girls' Engagement in Museum-Based Engineering Design Tasks
awd_abstract_narration:
Makerspaces and engineering design spaces have proliferated in science museums, schools, libraries, and community settings at a rapid pace. However, there is a risk that some of the same inequities that exist in the engineering field are being replicated in these settings. Research has provided evidence of persistent gaps between boys' and girls' levels of interest in engineering as it has been traditionally represented in informal learning environments, particularly in Making and engineering spaces. This Research-In-Service to Practice project intends to address this gap by employing a design-based research approach to examine if and to what extent narrative elements can interest and engage middle school girls in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM), and promote equitable, effective engineering design experiences and practices. This work is significant, as it will build upon current research and conceptual understanding of how to design narrative-rich engineering design activities for informal learning spaces, especially for girls, and within museum drop-in experiential learning contexts. It will also contribute to the evidence base regarding how girls approach and choose to persist in solving engineering design problems. The project is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. This includes providing multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences, advancing innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments, and developing understandings of deeper learning by participants.

The New York Hall of Science (NYSCI) in collaboration with the Amazeum in Bentonville, Arkansas, the Tech Museum of Innovation in San Jose, California, the Creativity Labs at Indiana University and a team of advisors will conduct the 30-month, design-based research project in two phases. In the first phase, NYSCI will garner ongoing input from its partners to develop parallel versions of six pairs of engineering design activities, one with narrative elements and one without. These activities will be iteratively tested in NYSCI's Design Lab, a 10,000 square foot exhibition devoted to hands-on exploration of engineering design.  Several research questions will be explored, focused primarily on building evidence-based design knowledge, establishing appeal and comprehensibility, and understanding facilitation. Observational and interview data will be garnered from 30 girls aged 7-14 and their family groups for each of the twelve activities developed, totaling 360 girls in the study sample. The results of the research on the paired activities will be iterative and provide insight on how narrative elements can most effectively invite girls into sustained engagement with the core engineering concepts and practices highlighted in each activity. In the second phase, formative and summative evaluation will be conducted to study the impact of the narrative and non-narrative versions of the engineering design activities on participating girls' engagement and persistence, by contrasting the quality of girls' engagement across the two types of activities while they are implemented across three museum sites.  Project deliverables include journal articles reporting on project findings; documentation of activities that meet project goals; design guidelines for exhibit and curriculum developers who are interested in using narrative effectively to frame engineering design activities; and practical guidance for facilitators seeking to ensure that they are supporting girls effectively as they explore those activities.

por.por_cntn:
Project overview: Recent research and policy developments in engineering education have described empathy as an integral part of the engineering design process. Engineers must empathize with clients and other stakeholders in order to understand their perspectives and design solutions that meet their needs. Yet engineering is often taught with abstract problems or competitive challenges, rather than human-centered approaches. This leads many learners, and particularly girls, to the conclusion that engineering is impersonal and disconnected from the issues and communities they care about. Reframing engineering education to center empathy for others has the potential to invite a wider range of identities into the field, while also helping all learners develop socioemotional skills that are critical for solving complex problems with societal and ethical implications.

In this project, a team of researchers, activity developers, and educators across four informal learning institutions (the New York Hall of Science, Scott Family Amazeum, Tech Interactive, and Creativity Labs at UC Irvine) investigated how narratives could be used to evoke empathy and support girls’ engagement in informal engineering activities. The team iteratively developed six pairs of engineering activities; each pair included one version of an engineering design activity with narrative elements (including characters, settings, and narrative problem frames) and one without. Through developing and testing these activities with girls ages 7-14, we investigated how materials and facilitation by museum educators could be used most effectively to convey a narrative context and how narratives evoked different facets of empathy (including emotional responses like compassion and concern, cognitive responses like perspective-taking, and prosocial actions to help others). By comparing the narrative and non-narrative versions of each activity, we examined whether and how the addition of narrative elements influenced girls’ engagement in key engineering design practices (such as defining the problem to be solved, generating design ideas, and testing and iterating designed solutions based on feedback).

NYSCI researchers observed and interviewed 190 girls (ages 7-14) in NYSCI’s Design Lab exhibition, and a summative evaluation included over 200 girls across the three museum sites involved in the project. We found that girls used more engineering practices in the narrative than the non-narrative activities, and that empathy was the driving factor in these findings: when participants expressed empathy, they participated in activities longer and used a greater range of engineering practices. We also found that narrative elements could evoke multiple facets of empathy when reinforced by the materials and facilitation within each activity, and that narratives were most effective when they provided starting points for learners’ choices and ideas, rather than relying on fully-developed storylines. Our iterative development and testing process resulted in a set of design principles for integrating narratives into engineering activities in ways that effectively evoked empathy and supported engineering goals. Finally, we developed a practitioner guide that includes: an overview of prior research on narratives and empathy and their link to engineering and gender equity; our process for developing narrative-based engineering activities; the design principles that emerged from our research; observation tools for documenting empathy and engineering practices in informal settings; facilitation strategies for narrative-based engineering activities; and descriptions of the six narrative-based activities that we developed and the decisions we made to strengthen empathy and engineering practices within each activity.

Intellectual Merit: This work advances knowledge in the informal STEM education field in multiple ways: First, our work builds on current research suggesting that human-centered approaches to engineering education can support deeper engagement than traditional engineering challenges for learners across genders and backgrounds. Second, this project extends research on the use of stories and narratives to foster STEM learning, by developing evidence-based strategies for integrating narratives into hands-on engineering activities in open-ended ways. Finally, our work resulted in methods for observing empathy and engineering practices in informal learning settings, which can be used in future research and by educators and activity developers to create more inclusive learning experiences.

Broader impacts: This project addressed the continuing underrepresentation of girls in engineering, with a focus on elementary and middle school years when STEM interests are emerging. Prior research suggests that girls’ needs and interests are not currently being met by traditional approaches to engineering education, and that what may be needed is an intentional emphasis on the connections between the things being designed and the people involved. By creating learning experiences with girls’ interests in mind, this study resulted in specific strategies that informal institutions can use to develop more inclusive engineering activities that stand to benefit not only girls, but also other groups of learners who tend not to be engaged by traditional engineering experiences. Our practitioner guide, research findings, and observational tools have been disseminated widely to museum professionals, educators, and researchers in the informal STEM learning and K-12 engineering education fields.
